title: Before 31 December 2017, will President Trump sign legislation removing the ACA's individual mandate to purchase health insurance?
preds: Depends on the weather for golfing in Florida

The Senate voted to waive the automatic cuts 91-8 on Thursday. So I believe DT will sign ASAP

The House has passed, as part of the government funding bill,  a waiver of the automatic cuts - which would allow signing of the tax bill before end-2017. However, the Senate may (or may not) strip this measure from their version  - it requires 60 votes. Some Republicans, like Rand Paul, are not in favor either. One difficulty of stripping the waiver is that the House would have to vote again on the amended bill - which would be difficult as they are reportedly leaving town now - so the Dems in the Senate may decide to acquiesce to the House version, not to be blamed for a government shutdown. See https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-21/house-approves-temporary-funding-to-avert-government-shutdown

Updating my previous forecast (again) due to the fact that the House just passed legislation to keep the government funded. It seems highly likely that the Senate will pass it today, too. This should clear the way for the tax bill to be passed before the end of the year.
Swinging back to 0 as it is doubtful that Senate Dems will agree to the PAYGO waiver which means it is unlikely to be included in the continuing resolution on the budget.

I am lowering my forecast once again, this time to 15 percent. Under a 2010 "pay-as-you-go" law, Congress has to offset any new spending or lower taxes with automatic cuts to Medicare and other programs. This law would create across-the-board spending cuts that the GOP would most likely not want to take responsibility for. In order to pay the tax bill without the spending cuts, Congress must pass a waiver that is not filibuster-proof. If President Trump waits until 2018 to pass the tax bill, Congress will have a full year to pass the waiver. At the moment, this seems like a much more likely possibility than trying to rush the passing the waiver before the end of the year.
Downgrading my previous forecast to 50 percent based on reports that the bill may not signed until January 2018. Whether the bill is signed in 2017 or 2018 appears to be a toss up at this point.

Downgrading my estimate based on new report from Rep. McCarthy. Apparently Trump may delay signature on tax overhaul bill (with repeal of ACA mandate) per request from businesses, who are required to re-calculate the impact of new laws on their balance sheets in the quarter that the President signs the bill into law. I doubt Trump wants to be known as the President who ruined Christmas for CEOs, CFOs and CPA's.
News story as of 12/20 that Trump may not sign tax bill until January
The Republicans Tax Bill will contain elimination of the INDIVIDUAL MANDATE I believe.

A repeal of the individual mandate is a part of the tax bill that passed the House earlier today and is expected to pass the Senate later this evening. Most reports suggest that the Senate will pass this bill this evening and that President Trump will most likely sign it before Christmas. That said, I think it's a near certainty that President Trump will sign legislation removing the individual mandate and it's highly likely that he will do so before the end of the year.

Repeal of the individual mandate remains in the proposed tax bill. The GOP apparently has enough Senate votes to pass it without having to rely on Sen. McCain, who is now home after treatment for his brain tumor. Sen. Collins, Corker, and Rubio have retracted their objections. The remaining question is when the vote will be scheduled. If it is not scheduled before 12/21, the chances of it passing fall drastically due to impending spending bill deadline.

Barring a sudden outbreak of political courage--or failing that, political common sense--in the Senate, this is scheduled to pass next week, probably Tuesday.  As soon as the Leader Of The Free World can wrap his tiny fingers around a pen, he'll sign it.

Repeal is in the conference committee bill. Rubio can be ignored unless Collins becomes a No but he's more likely to be appeased. Jones will be sworn in later so Corker and one more Senator can be lost.

New Alabama Senator Doug Jones will not be seated until at least January. This question specifies that the President must sign the individual mandate repeal before 31 December 2017. Senate Republicans now have increased incentive to resolve their new tax plan and associated individual mandate repeal this year before their 52 seat majority is reduced to 51 when Jones takes office. Therefore, the recent election of Jones actually increases the odds that this legislation will be signed in 2017. There is plenty of reason to believe that the individual mandate will still be in place on January 1, 2018, but don't be fooled into thinking that the election of Jones makes that scenario more likely.
Two names: Susan Collins and Doug Jones.

I had thought the Republican effort to repeat the ACA had been resolved earlier. However, the Senate version of the tax bill includes a provision to remove the individual mandate. However, despite controlling both the House and Senate, this does not mean that the individual mandate will be removed by 12/31/17. Senate/House conference committee still needs to reconcile both versions of the bill. At issue remains:
(1) Presenting a joint Senate/House tax bill that needs to address: the individual mandate (probably yes), SALT deduction (McConnell now wants to increase), medical expense deductions (lower threshold), mortgage deduction (key for GOP blue state reps), resolve number of individual tax brackets (5 vs. 7), estate tax,  corporate tax rate (20 vs. 22%), corporate AMT (effect on R&D), Johnson amendment (churches can lobby), teacher/student deductions.
These are sizeable issues with vested special interests that will take some negotiating [85% chance of success]
(2) Preventing deficit hawks from defecting due to the projected $1-1.5 trillion deficit [95% chance of success]
(3) Avoiding a government shutdown by passing a 2 week temporary spending patch this week due by 12/09 [90% chance of success]
(4) If #3 is passed, avoiding a government shutdown by passing a spending bill by 12/22 (needs 60 Senate votes) [75% chance of success]
(5) Resolving DACA, which Democrats and a few Republicans favor before #4 is done [70% chance of success]
(6) Finally, all of this happening before 12/31 [60%]
im thinking this option gets traded away for a budget bill and in turn gets used to bring up repeal again for fundraising purposes.

Modify odds since now bill is in Conference:
2. (a) House chose to go to conference [100%] 
(b) The repeal language survive conference and shows up in the consolidated bill [100%] AND 
(c) both Chambers passes the consolidated bill [90%] AND 
(d) both Chambers passes the consolidated bill before then end of the year [100%] AND 
(e) President Trump doesn't object to the final bill [95%, there could be chances something new creeps up into the final bill that Trump doesn't like and don't underestimate the Republicans' ability to fumble] AND 
(f) Trump physically signs it [98%]
= 84%
House and Senate negotiators thrashing out differences over a major tax bill are likely to eliminate the insurance coverage mandate at the heart of the Affordable Care Act, lawmakers say.

Some news made me reconsider the odds. There is intense lobby and push back from Corporations (and Chamber of Commerce) against the retention of the AMT. The AMT retains about 40 billions, chump change for a 1.5 trillion tax bill, but the Senate must follow some rules (to avoid filibuster),  Since this is more a corporate tax reform than anything else, the outcries would push the House to go to Conference, instead of just voting to pass the Senate bill. 
Second piece of info, it looks like they really want to do this before the end of the year, so I'll increase the odd it will pass before the end of the year.

The Senate version of the tax bill satisfies a "yes" on this question. I still think that either they will drop it to get all Republican senators on board, or the signing will be delayed beyond end-2017. But given that (i) the provision generates over $300 billion in "savings", which will have to be made up elsewhere if it's dropped, and (ii) the big push to have the tax bill done before end-2017, there is a non-zero probability that this may be a "yes".

In case you missed the news, the Senate Parliamentarian ruled that reconciliation procedures can only be used until the end of the fiscal year (30 Sep). Which means, and Graham-Cassidy reconciliation bill would have to pass in both chambers in the next 6 joint legislative days (https://www.senate.gov/legislative/resources/pdf/2017_calendar.pdf - Senate has 11 days; https://www.majorityleader.gov/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/2017_ANNUAL_CALENDAR.pdf - House has  6 days). According to WaPo, "But the two senators have yet to unveil their bill, and it would have to undergo a Congressional Budget Office analysis before coming to the floor for a vote. To pass it by a simple majority in the Senate, that vote would have to take place before the current budget resolution expires at the end of the month." (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/paloma/the-health-202/2017/09/08/the-health-202-governors-want-obamacare-fixes/59b18d5e30fb04264c2a1d3d/)

Skinny repeal failure tilts this heavily toward zero; however, the house bill made it out of the house, suggesting a vague consensus around a repeal-replace plan that can be acceptable to Republicans and that features removal of individual mandate.  With this in mind, the failure margin in the Senate is small - the skinny repeal failed 51-49, so only one senator needs to flip to bring in Mike Pence for a tie-breaker - I suspect McCain is the most likely candidate to flip. Nevertheless, McConnell has announced his intention to move past healthcare for this session of Congress.  Although President Trump continues to push and tweet about proceeding on healthcare, his administration recently experienced a divergence from the Republican establishment (resignation of Reince Priebus); this shift eliminates a key avenue for his pressure to actually bear fruit. As a result, Republican legislators face the same usual pressure they have since the 2010 midterms, namely their base wants to see something happen; they also face pressure from the optics of being totally in control of the government and yet failing to make a successful run at their signature issue of the last 7 years; and, as noted, they face pressure from the de facto leader of their party (POTUS).  In aggregate, there is still some chance legislation would be passed.

The individual mandate would not be very costly to offset with increased taxes or taxes from other sources.  Some sort of compromise with Democrats may yet be possible during tax reform or budget negotiations.  This would give Republicans some small measure of vindication after 7 years of promises.

I do not believe it's likely, but now there is seemingly a much greater chance than before.
The procedural vote to open debate just got to 50 with Senators Collins and Murkowski voting no..Pence will have to break the tie.

McCain is back in DC in order to go forward with at least the motion to proceed to debate.  If at least 50 Senators cave on the procedural vote, the votes on whatever slew of bills begins. There is a good chance of that happening..so what's next?
Bills voted on and fail, then votes on amendments, circling the wagons until they publicly pinpoint everyone's precise issue, attempt to buy them off and get something out. This could go on for days because McConnell seems hell bent on getting something done here. Previously, it seemed he wanted to move on but this strategy indicates otherwise.
This may change if the Senate ever figure out what they're being asked to vote on, but probably not.  Who knew health care could be so complicated?  Let's have a show of hands.
The Parliamentarian put more nails in the Trumpcare coffin. Problem is McConnell is still inside kicking.
No, the bill has died twice in the senate and I expect the straight repeal vote to die too. Plus with McCain back home in Arizona I really don't see a path forward for this idea.

And with the McCain news, an already tumultuous GOP wing of the Senate is sent into further disarray. This has big implications, not only for potential future health care efforts, but also tax reform, FY18 budget, and any other legislation McConnell had hoped to make progress on. McCain's absence means the GOP can only afford 1 defection in the future on legislation and removes the VP tiebreaker until the chamber is back to full strength.

http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/19/mccain-diagnosed-with-brain-tumor-240739
Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) has been diagnosed with a brain tumor following an operation to remove a blood clot above his left eye.
McCain and his family are considering options for treating the tumor, including radiation and chemotherapy. The 80-year-old McCain has previously successfully been treated for skin cancer.
Hard to imagine moderate republican senators voting for repeal.
Insurers won't be on board because where then does their revenue come from?

With Replace all but dead for the year, the attention turns to a bill written as a clean up or down vote on Repeal. but it will only serve as a checklist of yeas and neas for voter guides in 2018. With-out repeal or replace the strategy become one of attrition - starved of its mandate the ACA crashes inside of two years on its own.

I suppose now that Republicans can do what they do best, spend the next year trashing and crashing Obamacare. However, if Susan Collins and other women Senators (who ALL were excluded from the group of 13 men who crafted that failed bill) came together on a bill to only fix the markets, they would likely have the votes because Democrats (probably all of them) would support that. 
It has long been known that healthcare decisions are mostly made by the women in families and yet Republican leaders had the nerve not to include even one. Would Republican leaders block such a bill and not let it get a hearing?

Repeal-only has failed at this point (https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/trump-suggests-republicans-will-let-aca-market-collapse-then-rewrite-health-law/2017/07/18/5e79a3ec-6bac-11e7-b9e2-2056e768a7e5_story.html?tid=a_breakingnews?tid=a_breakingnews&hpid=hp_no-name_no-name%3Apage%2Fbreaking-news-bar). As @JMR2017 called, Capito, Collins, and Murkowski came out saying they would vote against repeal only legislation.

McConnell seems to be doubling down against his own caucus by forcing them to vote on repeal without replace. I realize his wife works for Trump but I thought his job was to keep a Republican majority and perhaps grow it. On repeal, they pick up Rand Paul and maybe a few others who said the last bad bill wasn't bad enough but I have to think most won't support and especially the women Senators (3 of the 5 Republican women Senators have indicated their concerns previously).

Yertle is flailing and M. Petits-Doigts is preparing a midnight Twitstorm, but even the knuckle-draggers in the House mayn't pass just a repealer with no substitute, with or without a two-year stall, and the Senate certainly won't.   Mr. Tangerine Man will threaten to arrange primary opposition for anyone who doesn't do his bidding, but there are still some residual adult impulses buried deep within enough members that it won't matter.  This issue is almost surely off the table for a while.

As noted by @JMR2017 and reported by various outlets (https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/amid-uncertainty-about-mccains-health-senate-returns-with-gop-agenda-in-flux/2017/07/17/6dd31530-6b02-11e7-9c15-177740635e83_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_mccain-210pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&utm_term=.b465b0d1aa2f), Sens. Lee and Moran have come out against BCRA. With three weeks in session, this is a major blow to the GOP effort to repeal the ACA. While it's possible the GOP can revise the bill sufficiently enough in the next week or so to gain full GOP support and push through the Senate for further fast tracking in the House (as I discussed in an earlier post: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/537012), it's unlikely this will be the case.
Senators Jerry Moran and Mike Lee have come out indicating that they will not support even a motion to proceed with the vote to repeal Obamacare. Therefore, McCain's absence doesn't matter.

He has to. The individual mandate is the defining characteristic of Obamacare, with its fines for those who go without, and because of this will score the biggest political windfall. Republicans have to have legislative victories going into next year--this is especially true for the individual representatives and senators, as they need something to highlight.

Slight increase back to my starting point based on House member comments that the Senate bill, if left as is, will likely pass a floor vote in the House without changes (https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/if--if--the-senate-passes-a-health-bill-get-ready-for-lightning-round-in-the-house/2017/07/15/522c8d08-68d1-11e7-a1d7-9a32c91c6f40_story.html?wpmm=1&wpisrc=nl_daily202). This signals that the GOP understands the challenges of getting the BCRA passed before the end of the FY (and their ability to use reconciliation until an FY18 budget resolution is passed), and that they will put aside factional differences to carry out a promise to constituents that's been 7 years in the making.

The Trump/McConnellCare plan is on life support right now with diminishing chances of a Senate version. With 2 Republicans strongly opposed to the bill (Sen. Collins, & Paul) and Sen. McCain recovering from a craniotomy due intracranial bleeding, the Senatorial procedural vote to proceed with debate will not take place for several weeks. Even if/when debate is permitted, if the bill continues to cut Medicaid funding several moderate Republicans (Sen. Heller, Murkowski, McCain) will likely vote against it. And this is even before factoring in debate on the effects of the potentially more harmful Cruz amendment.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Slight downgrade for the delay in the vote (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2017/07/15/with-sen-mccain-out-for-eye-surgery-vote-on-health-care-bill-uncertain/?hpid=hp_rhp-top-table-main_mccain919pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&utm_term=.815ece191822). The longer it takes to get to a vote, the less likely it becomes for them to pass it during FY17 using reconciliation. Assuming McCain recovers quickly, the Senate will have 3 weeks left in session after next week.

http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/15/mcconnell-senate-to-defer-obamacare-repeal-vote-240596
The Senate will "defer" consideration of its attempt to repeal and replace Obamacare, said Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell on Saturday night. The announcement follows Sen. John McCain's surgery that will keep him away from Washington next week. The bill has two GOP senators in opposition already and likely would have failed to advance with McCain's absence.

http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/lawmaker-news/341826-free-kevin-hassett-trumps-pick-a-victim-of-democratic
------------------------
"Once a given piece of legislation attracts bipartisan support, moderate Senate Republicans, who may otherwise waiver in their support, will find they can support the measure without the electoral risk that accompanies a strictly partisan measure. Political scientists call that “protecting one’s backside.
Indeed, in a Senate with only 52 Republican members, 60 votes may be easier to achieve than 51.”

As with all the legislation questions, there's a lot of moving parts. As of this morning, BCRA (the GOP health care bill in the Senate) doesn't have the requisite votes to pass. Additionally, CBO's scoring of the BCRA should come Monday, which will give a better idea of whether the holdout R's might come around to supporting or if BCRA becomes even more toxic. There's still a month left for the Senate to pass this legislation with McConnell delaying the August recess, so there's still time for them to get something passed.
